course.subject: LIFS
course.name: General Biology II
course.description: This course targets science students who have acquired basic knowledge in fundamental biology through HKDSE 1x Biology, AL/AS Biology or LIFS 1901. It functions as a bridging course to prepare the students for further study in life science. Its focus is on human biology, biotechnology and human impacts on the environment. Current examples will be used as well to relate the knowledge to real life issues. Students without the prerequisites but have completed biology course or program at equivalent level may seek instructorâ€™s approval for enrollment.
course.prerequisites: LIFS 1901 OR level 3 or above in HKDSE 1x Biology OR a passing grade in AL/AS Biology

reviews.author: TXH
reviews.comment_content:
Includes the following content (chronological order)
Miller's part:
1, Course introduction and nervous system
2, Musculoskeletal system
3, Heart and the Circulatory system
4, Respiratory system
5, Osmoregulation and Excretion
Li's part:
6, Digestive system
7, Endocrine system and Nutrition and Diseases
8, Lymphatic and immune system
9, Development and Aging
Liang's part:
10, DNA structure and Gene expression
11, Patterns of Gene Inheritance
12, Chromosomal Basis for Inheritance
13, Biotechnology
reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller:
Prof. Miller's lectures are very interesting, he uses simplified models and interesting examples to help students understand and remember the content, so you will find his lectures kind of attractive. However he will exclude some content in his ppts and mention them in class, and of course they will be seen in the test.

Li:
Acceptable teaching, she just basically explains the content on her ppts.

Liang:
As the course director, Prof. Liang will include some critical thinking questions in class for students to answer, some of which are interesting and meaningful for lifs students, and they might be explained in more advanced lifs courses. These questions could end up in the final exam!
Prof. Liang explains his lectures pretty clear, but not as interesting as Prof. Miller.

My overall rating: Miller>Liang>Li
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 50%
Content: All Miller's lectures and Li's first two lectures
Final: 50%
Content: Li's second two lectures and all Liang's lectures
Rumors say that the test papers are all identical each year, so no past-papers can be found or provided.

In my case Prof. Miller went slow on his lectures and we only had time to go over his first three lectures, so there was a lot of non-essential content in the midterm. BEWARE OF ALL THE NAMES IN MILLER'S LECTURES! EVEN THE NON_SCIENTISTS! For example, in our midterm there was s question asking about who Simone de Beauvoir was. (She was a french writer who argued against Sigmund Freud).

My scores:
Midterm:70/75     Mean 51.5    High 71
Final: 57/75           Mean 42.1    High 66
Eventually: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework, a lot to remember!

Li's lectures are usually the longest and has the most content, I suggest that you spend time after every lecture to memorize the vocab and content. If you leave it to the last minute, you won't end up with decent grades.

Liang's lectures contain DNA structure and gene expression, which in my opinion is the hardest part in this class, not too much to remember, but some could be hard to understand.

As for Miller, there is not too much to memorize in his lectures, and under his explanation the hard concepts will be easy to understand.

Overall(In my opinion)
Difficulty: Liang>Li>Miller
Workload: Li>Liang>Miller

reviews.comment_content:
Professor Miller :
Course Introduction and Nervous system (17)
Musculoskeletal System (19)

Professor Li:
Digestive System and Nutrition (14)
Endocrine System (20)

- [ Mid-term exam ] ----------------------------------------------

Patterns of gene inheritance (23)

reviews.comment_teaching:
[1.] Prof. Miller:
The content he taught is the simplest of the 3 instructors and well organized. He teaches with passion and is witty.

He is friendly and gentle, but the question he asked wasn't.

You have to remember every word, every single detail of every slide. You have to remember the name of the scientists and their work.

If you can't see a word on a picture, use a microscope if you can cause it will probably appear in the test.

[2.] Prof. Li :
Li's content is easy to understand but having too many contents and topics in my opinion.

Her ppt was not well organized. You will see many pictures and words in her ppt and only very few of them will be asked.

If you dare to differentiate which part is useful or not, it is not as hard as it appears.

She is kind but not very experienced in teaching I assume, all she did was reading form the ppt.

[3.] Prof. Liang
The content he taught was HARD, very HARD to understand but was equally interesting. Comparing to the previous content, the complexity was like an abrupt turn.

The concepts of topics he taught were very very challenging, remarkably hard to understand and too many to be memorized. If you can't understand the concept there is no way you know his questions in the exam.

His teaching is intriguing, he will ask many questions related to the content and allow the student to think. Like why is DNA polymerase works like this but not that, how can the experiment be done to verify the hypothesis, etc.

Very engaging and thought-provoking but can be tedious for some.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term exam(50%)
Final exam(50%)

- 75 MCQ
- close book exam

Very straight forward questions.
If you are hard-working enough, you will be rewarded with a good grade.

Mid-term (65/75)
Mean: 51.5 High: 71

Final (63/75)
Mean: 42.1 High: 66

Overall: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework, no assignment.

Tons of ppt memorization.

Cramming is extremely painful in this course.
Thus don't cram and organize your notes from time to time.

the content of this course is fragmented so it is not that important to think about the relationship between the topics.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Miller is a passionate person. He likes the Simpsons so he always put a lot of Simpsons cartoons in his slides. His slides is vivid and he always hightlights the important points so that you will know which one you should pay attention to. But actually all the contents in his slides are important because even if some digression in his slides is not related to biology, it will also appear in exam. By the way, if you have any questions, he will be happy to answer you even if he sometimes murmured the questions were too much.

Dr Li is a young woman so she is not that experienced in teaching compared to other two instructors. One tips is that her slides includes too many concepts and she will only put the concepts mentioned in the lectures in the exam. So you should pay more attention during the lecture because she will not underline which one is important in her materials.

Prof Liang's slides are well organized making it easier to be understood. But you should spend more time on his slides because the part he tought was the hardest in 1902 (not that hard if you have learned the fundamental DNA and inherit when you are in high school, likes students from mainland choosing biology in JEE). He likes to gives us some thinking questions during the lecture and you are supposed to follow him because it can make you think critically and better understand the concept.
reviews.comment_grading:
if you want to get a good grade. the only thing you need to do is to memorize the material in the ppt.
again, memory is the most important in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: no homework. but you are supposed to go over the ppt after each lecture becuase it is very hard to memorize all the contents of the ppt only a few days before the exams.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Miller
: The best lecturer among the course professors. He uses some effective analogy to make students understand the concepts. He's also keen to answer the students' questions during or after the lecture.

**Some tips: He really loves the details in his ppt slides. Make sure to memorize minor things in his ppt even it doesn't seem to be related to biology.**

Professor Li
: The chapters that she's in charge of requires a fairly large amount of memorization. Her teaching is good enough for understanding the concepts but sometimes the lecture pace is so fast. (maybe due to a lot of contents to cover in a limited time span)

**Some tips: Don't try to memorize everything in her ppt slides. Only focus on the things she mentions during the lecture.**

Professor Liang
: Professor Liang sometimes questions about why a certain phenomenon is happening and why should it work in that way during the lecture. He gives students some time to answer his questions. These questions can be critical for understanding the concepts in his part. Make sure to know what is the right answer to the question.

All three professors have different teaching styles. It would be good for your study to know their teaching styles and respond to their style properly each time the professor changes.
reviews.comment_grading:

Final Exam (50%)

All closed-book, 75 questions each (all MCQ)

Straightforwardly, the majority of questions in the exams ask whether you memorized the right things correctly. Others ask you to deduce certain things in the given problem.
Surprisingly, no calculating problems in the genetics chapter at all which is somewhat disappointing.

mid-term (64/75) (highest: 71)
final (63/75) (highest: 66)

Overall: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
50% mid-term, 50% final. No workload.

I recommend whoever attends this lecture to attend the real-time class and write down your own lecture notes(with details) right after the lecture.

Be diligent, or it can be a great burden to organize lecture contents and then memorizing those things.

reviews.comment_teaching:
MILLER:
My favorite part in bio is human physiology, so Miller's lectures where very enjoyable and easy to learn. There was new content not covered in IB Bio, but they are not complicated. WARNING: Miller has a whole lecture on psychology/pschoanalysis and lots of seemingly unrelated info on Nobel prizes/random facts. GET THAT RANDOM INFO DOWN. Being fluent in English helps immensely with this. If you are not fluent in English, you will need to memorize these facts. Fortunately, Miller's ppt's are comprehensive and required little additional notes. Miller's pace is also slower than the other two profs, which is good for learning but he doesn't finish planned content. He only tests on taught content, so no worries.
Miller also has a strong sense of humor that some
absolutely love and others find unbearably distracting. I loved it.

LI:
Her ppts includes a lot of images and diagrams, but lack words. I had to rewatch lecture videos and type out notes. Li's sentences don't flow as smoothly as Miller's (I suppose because she has less experience). This is not a problem during lessons, but becomes one when having to type out notes. Rewatching lecture and typing out notes was very frustrating and unnecessarily time-consuming, especially since typing out all key points during lectures is practically impossible. However, Li is very kind and willing to answer students questions.

LIANG
Clear passion and difficult content. His ppts contain a good amount of content, but not everything, so rewatching and typing out notes is definitely needed.  I found the content very difficult in comparison with Miller's and Li's, however (I imagine) it is the basis of the rest of the biology classes. Liang also includes brief Chinese/Cantonese idioms/sayings to explain certain things. It's just an extra and does not (at least from what I see) affect the understanding of non-Chinese speakers. Despite how much I like Liang's teaching, I found studying his content an absolute pain

reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller is very nice, interesting and passionate. His lectures are vivid. Important points are hightlighted to help you revise. If you have any questions, he is always willing to answer.
All the contents in his slides are important. Even something not related to biology, e.g. history, people's names about the Nobel Prize,  will also appear in exam.

Li is nice but not experienced in teaching. Her slides includes too many concepts, but most of them are pictures.. The important explanation and something that you must memorize are all spoken by her mouth... So you must listen to and record her explanations carefully in order to not missing any details... Also, she will not underline important materials in most of the slides.

Liang is passionate and helpful.  His slides are well organized. To help you understand more clearly, he upload some videos on Canvas. One tip is that you should spend more time on his slides because his part is the hardest in 1902, esp. the gene expression part.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller:
He is a passionate prof. and the lecture is lively, ppt has funny slides, and he sometimes makes jokes. But pay attention that he will include slides that are not found in canvas (as a way to encourage us to attend lectures) and sometimes he will say that which slides will be included in the exam. The exam from miller's part is easy overall. But since his ppt includes some cartoon illustrations, for those who only read ppt, it is sometimes quite misleading. And the contents of his lecture sticks to the syllabus/book

Liang:
His part is the hardest (dna)( so be prepared by the hard Qs in the exam), so u will need more time to prepare and understand his parts, his ppt is very organised and separated different parts with colour. He will include more extra information apart from the lecture, and u should prepare that in exam, but if the extra content is really out of syllabus, he will tell u that part is not required in the exam. And his exam Q is tricky and not as straight forward as miller's and raymond's.

Raymond:
He talks very slowly in class and he always can't finish the slides in the lectures (bear in mind that he has retired and is just helping some parts of the course). He includes some extra information in the biochemistry field since he is the expert of that. But his exam is not as hard since most of the time extra content is not involved. If u like to know more and love research, u may like liang's and raymond's lectures.

In terms of difficulty and preparation to get high marks in exam:
Miller<Raymond<<<Liang

reviews.comment_content:
Content is really interesting, obviously there's a lot of understanding involved but if you like biology, you'll like the course.

Week 2 - Chromosomal Basis of Inheritance - TANG
Week 3 - Biotechnology - TANG
Week 4 - Reproductive System - TANG
Week 5 - Development - HO
Week 6 - Digestive System - HO
Week 7 - Respiratory System - MILLER
Week 8 - Excretory System & Osmoregulation - MILLER
Week 9 - Immune System - HO

reviews.comment_teaching:
All of the professors are good.
Professor Tang reviewed the content and made us do group discussions.
Professor Ho reviews the topic by asking questions to certain groups and giving us crossword puzzles to do in class.
Professor Miller is the best in terms of understanding, he explains the most important points and then each group watches a video and answers questions about the video.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading -
Online quiz - 10%
Participation - 10%
Final exam - 60%
Short Essay - 20%
None of the marks were released apart from the online quiz. I got A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
We have to watch the module videos every week and complete a quiz. As semester goes on the modules get longer and longer, videos go from being 5 minutes to 30 minutes, with 4-6 videos in each module, so it is quite time consuming.
Apart from this, there's a short 400 word essay, it's not that hard, the essay titles are quite straight-forward. It only took me about an hour for everything including research.

reviews.comment_teaching:
MILLER:
My favorite part in bio is human physiology, so Miller's lectures where very enjoyable and easy to learn. There was new content not covered in IB Bio, but they are not complicated. WARNING: Miller has a whole lecture on psychology/pschoanalysis and lots of seemingly unrelated info on Nobel prizes/random facts. GET THAT RANDOM INFO DOWN. Being fluent in English helps immensely with this. If you are not fluent in English, you will need to memorize these facts. Fortunately, Miller's ppt's are comprehensive and required little additional notes. Miller's pace is also slower than the other two profs, which is good for learning but he doesn't finish planned content. He only tests on taught content, so no worries.
Miller also has a strong sense of humor that some
absolutely love and others find unbearably distracting. I loved it.

LI:
Her ppts includes a lot of images and diagrams, but lack words. I had to rewatch lecture videos and type out notes. Li's sentences don't flow as smoothly as Miller's (I suppose because she has less experience). This is not a problem during lessons, but becomes one when having to type out notes. Rewatching lecture and typing out notes was very frustrating and unnecessarily time-consuming, especially since typing out all key points during lectures is practically impossible. However, Li is very kind and willing to answer students questions.

LIANG
Clear passion and difficult content. His ppts contain a good amount of content, but not everything, so rewatching and typing out notes is definitely needed.  I found the content very difficult in comparison with Miller's and Li's, however (I imagine) it is the basis of the rest of the biology classes. Liang also includes brief Chinese/Cantonese idioms/sayings to explain certain things. It's just an extra and does not (at least from what I see) affect the understanding of non-Chinese speakers. Despite how much I like Liang's teaching, I found studying his content an absolute pain

reviews.comment_content:
1. Explain the basic structures and life processes in humans.
2. Explain basic inheritance of traits in humans.
3. Explain basic biotechnology and discuss their impact on human life.
4. Discuss the relevance of life science to the study of the human as a living organism.

Week 1 - Patterns of Gene Inheritance
Week 2 Chromosomal Basis of Inheritance
Week 3 - Biotechnology
Week 4 Reproduction
Week 5 Development
Week 6 Digestive system and Nutrition
Week 7 Immune System
Week 8 Endocrine system

reviews.comment_teaching:
It is a Blended-Learning course. Nice teaching. We need to spend half our time reviewing the online material and half our time attending tutorials.

There are always group discussions in the tutorial. We need to answer the question to get participation marks.
reviews.comment_grading:
Components Percentage

Online quiz 10
Participation mark 10
Written assignment * 20
Final exam 60
*Each student is required to write a 400- word essay on one of the assigned topics. Topics will be related to the content of the weekly videos or tutorials.   

The quiz is not so difficult, it is easy to get full marks in these quizzes.
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload. There is one quiz for each topic each week. The quiz contains 10 MCQ.

But watching the video is really time-consuming. So many terms and principles need to remember.

At the end of the semester, we are asked to write an essay. The professor will randomly assign two essay topics to each of us. And we chose one topic from two of them to write a 400-words essay.  

The essay will be related to the topic we learned this semester, and let you introduce application or background, etc.

reviews.author: ggg_
reviews.title: Work hard to memorize the contents and everything will be fine
reviews.comment_content:
Before Midterm:
Prof. MILLER: nerves, muscles, heart, lungs
Prof. LI: Digestive system, Endocrine system
After Midterm:
Prof. LI: Lymphatic & Immune system, Development & Aging
Prof. LIANG: DNA structure and gene inheritance, Patterns of inheritance, Chromosomal basis of inheritance, Biotechnology

To be honest the content structure is a bit strange. It goes from physiology to DNA and inheritance. I don't think it is the typical order of learning Biology but there's nothing else to do rather than accept it. The part taught by Prof MILLER and LI is basic physiology. Part of the contents taught by Prof. LIANG overlaps with the contents in senior high (mainland)(It's like the English version of it, but of course a little more in-depth). The vocabulary may be larger compared with other subjects, but it is acceptable once you get familiar with the prefixes and word roots, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. MILLER is kind and just like your grandpa. His lectures are engaging and interesting. But his slides is a bit unorganized and he taught about lots of 'useless' and 'unnecessary' staff like the people winning Nobel Prize etc. The lecture on Nerves is totally transformed into psychiatry, about Freud and other mental illnesses. HOWEVER those seemingly 'useless' staff will appear in your midterm exam(even the female writer that wrote against Freud). So try to remember everything covered.

Prof. LI is young and seems to be new in teaching. Her class is not so engaging as her tones seldom rise or drop and she seems to be not so familiar with the content. But her ppts are neat, and the structure is very clear. There are many pictures on her ppt, which are important for having a good understanding of the stuff she is talking about. Pictures didn't occur in the exams but you'd better study and memorize them. In my opinion, her exam questions are not so straightforward as prof. MILLER and is more challenging. It's easy to get confused.

Prof. LIANG's accent is a little strange but it doesn't affect understanding. He usually raises some questions for students to think about. The questions are worth thinking. Sometimes he gives the answer, but sometimes he didn't state it quite clearly either. It greatly improves my ability to search for relative materials to find reasonable explanations. Some of the questions may appear in the test. His ppts are just fine.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think if you work hard to be familiar with and memorize all the contents you will get a decent grade. To some extent, the outcome is proportional to your input.  The midterm and final are composed of only multiple-choice problems. No long questions. Only the contents covered after midterm is tested in the final.
Midterm: 70/75
Final: unknown
Overall: A+
reviews.comment_workload: There is no assignment and quizzes, only midterm and final. And only MC in them. But you should spend enough time going over the slides and sorting things out in your own way after each lecture continuously. If you leave all the work till the exams, you'll get mad. So the workload is not light.

Week 12: Nervous System

Basically, you need to attend all tutorials which are once per week. All the materials are similar to DSE level or slightly harder. Personally, week 5 which is about Development is the most difficult one since it is not taught before in DSE. Other than that all the concepts were taught in DSE so I think it is wasting my time.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Different styles.
For the first 4 weeks, professor Tang asked us to fill in the blanks and do worksheets with groupmates.
Week 5-8, professor Ho asked us to answer questions and think of some questions with groupmates.
Week 9-12, professor Miller arranged us to have short presentations about some videos.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online quiz 20%
Written assignment 20%
Final exam 60%
Answer questions in the tutorial will give you bonus marks. I don't know how much does it contribute to my grade but make sure you answer at least once every time.

We need to complete the online quiz (12 in total, week1 and 2 are not graded) one day before the tutorial and everyone should get nearly full marks on this part.

You need to write a 400 essay on a topic for the written assignment. Professors should release the topic of the essay earlier but you should have enough time to finish it.

90MC in 90mins for the final exam. Marks will be deducted for wrong answers. Some questions have multiple answers as well. You can't go back to previous questions.

My grade: A+
The score of the written assignment and the final exam is not published
reviews.comment_workload:
Complete online quiz one day before tutorial (around 10MC)
One 400 word essay in which you can choose your topic out of 3 choices.

reviews.author: Chenwei SHI
reviews.title: Just try hard to memorize
reviews.comment_content: content is usual.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller's teaching is so great. His ppt is easy for us to understand and his summary also provide a good opportunity to memorize the content.
I think Li Laam maybe not familiar with teaching, because her lecture is just read the ppt in most time but her powerpoint is also not easy to  memorize.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is not too high either too low i think. It is just usual.
reviews.comment_workload: It seems that the assignments are only Mid-term exam and Final exam. But actually if you don't spend much time memorizing the concepts in your spare time,  your grade probably would not be good.

reviews.author: Mits
reviews.title: Pre-requisite course for LIFS students
reviews.comment_content:
The course content is quite easy if you have taken higher level Biology courses in high school.
The topics are same as those in high school but the content is taught in more depth.

Course Structure :-
Course Introduction and Nervous system
Musculoskeletal System
Heart and the Circulatory system
Respiratory system
Osmoregulation and Excretion
Digestive System and Nutrition
Endocrine System
Lymphatic and Immune Systems
Development and Aging
        DNA structure and gene expression
Patterns of gene inheritance
        Chromosomal basis of inheritance
Biotechnology
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Miller is one of the best teachers at UST.
He is very humorous and includes funny examples in his ppt slides. Prof. Miller is also very interactive and open to answering any questions that you have.
(He was the best teacher among the three).
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair.
There are only two exams - midterms and final.
The first half of the portion appears in the midterms and the second half appears in the finals.
Both account for 50% of the course grade.

*Attendance for lectures is not compulsory
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is moderate.

Since there are no assignments and you only have to appear for two exams, you do not have to worry about weekly deadlines.

A lot of revision is needed to do well in the exams as the course content is vast. Thorough knowledge of each topic present in the lecture slides is required.
Also, the questions in the exam are also not focused on the lecture slides alone, the Professors include extra bonus questions that are based on the topics mentioned during the lecture which do not appear on the ppt slides.

reviews.author: mc_cch
reviews.title: Work hard
reviews.comment_content:
Prof. MILLER
1. Nerve
2. Muscle
3. Heart

Prof. Li
4. Digestive & nutrition
5. Endocrine system
6. Lymph & immunity
7. Development & ageing

Prof. Liang
8. DNA structure & gene expression
9. pattern of gene inheritance
10. chromosomal basis of inheritance
11. Biotechnology


# Don't be a deadline fighter
# Don't burn the midnight oil
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professors are very nice in general.

Prof. MILLER tried to make funny jokes in the lecture, but if you read through the ppt slides before, you might think he is just wasting yr time.   His ppt slides may include lots of irrelevant info. and pics. But he is still patient and willing to answer our questions.

I like Dr. Li the most.  She is a very young woman that she explained the concept clearly and allow us to ask questions in the midway of the lessons. Her lecture notes included many diagrams and structures that were hard to memorize. Some minor concepts were missed. She also provided a chance for students to talk to her face-to-face after the exam if they have any difficulties.

As Prof. Liang comes from Mainland China, he has a strong accent in English. Luckily,  he spent lots of time to explain the concepts of genetic (as this was the most difficult part of the syllabus).
reviews.comment_grading:
Although we spent plenty of time to memorize lots of stuff in the course materials, some questions in the exam were quite tricky....
But I think the grade is acceptable.

Mid-term:  51/75 (Mean: 51.5)  (50%)
Final: 44/75 (Mean: 42.1)   (50%)

Overall: B
reviews.comment_workload:
You hv to memorize a lot  of stufff...


If you find this course interesting, it would be easier for u to get a good grade.

reviews.author: L'amour, La vie
reviews.title: A standard course
reviews.comment_content:
You can see other comments for the course content. Nothing special.

Yes I admit that it is something that tests your memory. The things in the course are not very difficult to be honest, and around 70 percent of the exam questions are testing your memory. By memory I mean you can look up the answers in the lecture notes to answer that question without thinking. The remaining 30 percent are testing your understanding. The level of difficult of content is:
Miller's < Li Laam < Liang Chun.

Please attend every lecture of Li, Laam because she will ask some questions for which she has only mentioned during lectures, but not in her ppt.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller is a good old man who is fun and enthusiastic. What he tests during exams are also quite straightforward and easy. I think it is partly due to the fact that the topics he is in charge is easier compared with the other two professors.

Li, Laam is standard. She makes some jokes and gives you a break during lecture. However, what I do not like is her terrible powerpoints; she just copies photos from getty images and shutterstock and leaves a line of description. The point is that there are tons of useless content within those photos and you need to work hard to differentiate what is useless and what is not. So the best thing to do is to attend every of her lessons.

Liang's lecture is not really brilliant. His lecture is the most difficult one to be understood. It is understandable because the topics he is in charge is the most difficult one. However, his powerpoints are more organized than Li Laam's. But still, not very organized, which adds workload to organize them. Be noted, however, that his exam questions are very very difficult. Almost all of his exam questions are testing both your understanding and memory. I would say it is very easy to score low in his questions
reviews.comment_grading:
It is not really bad. But still, it requires input to get a good grade.

Mid-term: 57/75, highest: 71, lowest 0.
Final: 52/75, highest 66, lowest 0.
Final grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is acceptable. Effort is mainly spent in organizing the messy powerpoints of Li Laam's and Liang Chun's, plus understanding the course content when it gets difficult.

Depends on what you want to achieve, for me , I was a stupid freshman . I focus too much on learning the additional stuff, so my grades in other courses are not that good (Crying emoji)

By the way , I made some good friends during this course.
Therefore , don't be afraid to say hi to your neighbor. Choosing a person with no friends aside have a higher chance of success than choosing a group of people. That's because those group of people are usually met in ocamp, and they will bond with themselves so well that you can't even engage in their conversations, then you will just awkwardly sitting next to them after saying hi.
I found my friends when asking professors questions.

Kind reminders, don't focus on understanding the details , this is just a introductory course , those details will probably be taught in other courses

I think skipping lessons are fine, if you can do self learning
I didn't even watch those recorded videos after suspension of classes (starting from 6/11/2019 )

Gosh ! can't go to ust and have lessons for the entire year! I miss ust

reviews.author: LLLEE
reviews.comment_content:
It covers topics from circulatory system, lymphatic system, nutrition, hormones, to DNA and biotechnology etc. It would be an advantage if you still remember what have been taught in secondary school of course, but even if you forgot most of the content, you can easily catch up by searching on google.

It somehow explores further depth in details on each topic and you may feel frustrated at first, however, instead of reading the textbook to understand the whole ideas (which I used to), I recommend to search on google simply because the textbook doesnâ€™t cover all details mentioned in lectures and you will not be able to have a full picture if you just read the textbook.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller is enthusiastic in teaching, however, you canâ€™t simply understand the ppt if you do not attend his lectures because he tends to insert quite a lot of pictures and types less words, so you have to listen carefully to make sure what is meant by each slide. (His ppts are different from the ones he posted on canvas but he will upload the full version before exam) Also, he teaches fast. Somehow it is hard to catch up for me.

Raymondâ€™s teaching pace is slower than the other two, he loves to share his research results to us. Regarding his teaching, his ppt is quite confusing because he just copies the slides from google and insert them into his ppt without clear organization. Again, make sure you attend his lectures if you want to understand what is going on.

Liang chun is responsible for teaching us the DNA and biotechnology parts, he loves to ask students questions during classes (but itâ€™s not relate to the exam). His ppt is easy to be followed, but some of the details he will not include in his ppt (which will be examined), make sure you jot notes during his lectures.

Luckily, the videos will be posted on canvas so it is a good new for those who do not attend lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm (50%): 50 MCQ, conducted in lecture hall
Final (50%): 50 MCQ, conducted online

Midterm: 47/50
Final: 41/50 (mean: 32.5)
Final grade: 88/100 (A)
My friend got 84/100 but still got A so the range is quite wide.
reviews.comment_workload:
Please study and do extra search after lessons.
For me, I have made some notes for my revision, itâ€™s just my habit.
Recommend to revise for the exam 3-4 days before (I do so 1 day before and I feel painful to memorize all the stuff in one day)

reviews.author: TommyYin
reviews.comment_content: The contents are average things you need to know about biology. Nothing special.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Miller has the best accent and elaboration(probably because he's a native speaker). Prof. Wong speaks much slower and sometimes puts you to sleep. Prof. Liang seems to explain everything in a quite easy way. However, he never emphasizes what's going to be the focus of the exam, so you have to remember absolutely everything in his slides(probably more to explore yourself on the internet).
reviews.comment_grading: Overall not bad
reviews.comment_workload: If you love biology and have a gift for memorizing, then the whole course is gonna be a piece of cake for you. If you hate the process of endless strange words to memorize and the risk of unable to understand even the questions in the exam, then go to LIFS1901.

reviews.comment_content:
Most topics are closely related to HKDSE Biology, such as Digestive system, osmoregulation, chromosomal inheritance, etc, but it's getting a little intense.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Miller is funny, energetic and intelligent, his lectures are worth-attending.

Raymond's lecture is very boring that he speaks in low pace and weak tone, it's tiring to concentrate. But he is very kind that he will tell you tips.

Liang Chun is a very educated person but he is weak in delivering his knowledge and his English is bad, talk with him more to understand what's real.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Mr. Miller is quite nice, but his teaching is still mediocre, therefore, the thumbs-up is for his passion for his teaching. Besides, since Prof Miller is a British, you don't have to worry about the accent, he speaks quite a legit British English.

But for Miss Jessica, totally horrible!
She just reads the powerpoint slides without making further elaboration. I guess the only thing good about her teaching is that she would play music during the break time.

Lastly for Prof Raymond, no comment.

overall grade is A-

reviews.comment_workload: No workload, just some online canvas quizzes which won't be counted towards your final grade. On top of that, you would have one mid-term and one final. The content included in each is exam is quite heavy, therefore, be hard-working on them.

reviews.author: Adrianyu
reviews.title: A good grade course that requires certain effort
reviews.comment_content:
The content of LIFS 1904 is quite broad, ranging from genetic to human physiology. But I would say most of the contents are pretty much revisions of DSE biology.

Before mid-term:
-Digestive system (Wong)
-Lymphatic and immune system (Wong)
-Muscle (Ho)
-Kidney (Miller)*
-Cardiovascular system (Miller)
-Respiratory system (Miller)

After mid-term (all Tang)
-Biotechnology
-Nervous system*
-Endocrine system*
-Reproduction*
-Development and aging*
-Gene inheritance
-Chromosomal basis of inheritance*
(Those have stars are the topics that require more effort to study for me)

Contents are not cumulative in the exam.  So I would say revision by going through all the lectures is a really good method to secure you a good grade. It could help you cover all the trivial matters quickly.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Miller: I think he is the better lecturer of this course this semester. He goes through concepts really clearly and reminds us of the main points of his content frequently. Just follows what he asks you to remember is good enough to deal with his questions.

Professor Wong: Not so good compared with other lecturers. I fell asleep several times when I am having his lectures. Probably because of his word pace is too slow. Maybe the best part is that he never finishes his ppt. Less content for revision. Also, he frequently gets off-tracked by himself and repeats what he has mentioned before.

Professor Tang: A really kind-hearted lecturer. She holds tutorials for us, which is good. She goes through all the things smoothly but sometimes pretty boring.

Professor Ho: Just has one lecture. No comment.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term: pretty easy. 60 MCs in total.  However, there are several questions that test you some really trivial matters. Other questions are mostly normal and straight-forward.

Final exam: more challenging. 100 MCs including 5 multiple answer MCs. Maybe the topics tested are something new for DSEers, so I would say it is more challenging. The MC requires you to think more compared to the mid-term.

Mid-term score: 55/60
Final score: unknown
Grade: A range
reviews.comment_workload: I would say the workload is very light as there are just 2 exams in total. Especially for those who studied biology before, most of the topics are just reviews of what you should have previously learned. Just need to go through all the lectures before the exam is good enough for you to attain a really good grade.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Liang and Dr. Lam are local who's English's above average (among all local Prof. here). Prof. Liang is good at raising questions in your mind.(Cuz foundational knowledge on certain concepts are missing on ppt e.g. why DNA replication goes from 5' to 3', instead, it would only be taught in class. Unfortunately, for most of the students that sleep in class, they will find it extremely difficult to follow up)

Dr. Lam is a nice guy, before class, he would send you a notification email about the topics he'll teach. Also, he would send a summary abt the topics he taught soon after class.

Herrup is a foreign Prof. that should deserve more respect. He's actually an expert in neuroscience and was on a TV show before(you can just search it on YouTube). I don't think it is useful to say much abt him here.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fun fact that the Prof. don't really change the exam papers all these years. You will be like winning a lucky draw if You had found any past papers.(Make sure you have read once before the exam, cuz I have found at least 10% of them are the same as the one I was doing),(It's kind of weird, not many ppl know abt this 'secret' ^^)

To all the guys that screw up mid-term, PLZ DON'T GIVE UP ON THIS SUBJECT YET. The final exam is much much much much easier that mid-term.(to me it was...cuz you don't have to deal with DNA)

I had, that's why I only spent 15 mins per day for revision and I promise I knew more than anyone in class(except for the Prof.><)

reviews.comment_content: The course extends upon the GCE A level biology that I took in high school, and broadens one's biological understandings

reviews.author: Erfan
reviews.title: Lots of Content but Interesting
reviews.comment_content:
If you've done IB biology HL, this course is going to be kinda nice. Some parts have much more detail than the IB content and some parts are gonna have much less so it balances out.

Get ready to memorize a lot for this course, especially for the developmental biology, and then get ready to have a deep understanding of biological theories and systems, especially for endocrinology and evolution.

Overall, it's a standard biology course that just needs lots of revision and memorization. I'd definitely suggest studying from the textbook (you can find the pdf version from higher year students) off the written chapters as well as the PPT lectures notes BUT, only study the textbook parts that have been mentioned in the lecture notes first (textbook has lots of excess information)

Here's the general outline of the course

Introduction; DNA structure and gene expression (25)
Patterns of Gene Inheritance (23); Chromosomal Basis of Inheritance (24)
Development (22)
Reproduction (21)
Endocrine System (20)
Evolution (27)
Aging (22)
Circulatory System (12)
Respiratory System (15)
Lymphatic, Immune Systems & Infectious Diseases (13)
Osmoregulation & Excretion (16)
Digestive System and Nutrition (14)
Biotechnology (26)
Nervous System
Aging
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Herrup is an absolutely amazing lecturer. He speaks very fluently with a sense of passion about the topic and gets all excited about the content that he's lecturing on, which is always great. With all that being said, his PPTs/lecture notes are EXTREMELY confusing and disordered to the point where even he himself gets all confused as to what he's supposed to talk about next. Maybe it's a good technique for forcing students to show up to the lecture, since the notes make no sense otherwise. Make sure to jot down the things he says, they're pretty interesting even if they don't come up on the finals. (He asks general questions about what biology is all about and how systems interact with each other that some find hard but I find more useful)

Professor Lam is great. Clear speaking, clear lecture notes, a really sweet guy. Again, there's a small issue with how he controls the noise level in the lectures, aka, he doesn't.

Professor Liang looks really experienced in his field and very passionate for his work in genetics and cancer research HOWEVER he's just not a good lecturer. Simple as that. Not everyone can handle a class of 300 people while speaking eloquently, it's a fact. Just study from the textbook and his PPTs it's all good (He asks lots of questions in the exam that need only memorization)
reviews.comment_grading:
The exams are almost identical to the IB Biology Paper 1, so kinda tricky and not so straight forward. I personally like the way they're written since it rewards students who spend time actually learning rather than memorizing a bunch of content like zombies.  

There is one mid-term (50%) and one final (50%), each containing their own half of the semester with approximately 5MCQs from each lecture. There's 52-54 questions.

I got an A overall but I don't think it's that easy to get an A range since most people around me who did well in the exams ended up with a B/

-Midterms I got a 42/50 with mean 32.7 out of 50 and a SD of 8.0

-Finals I'm almost sure I got around 51/54 but the actual scores were never released.
reviews.comment_workload: Lots of memorization but that's basically all.

reviews.author: J.T.
reviews.comment_content:
before midterm: DNA Structure and Gene Expression, Evolution, Development, Respiratory System, Endocrine System and Reproduction

after midterm: Circulatory System, Immune System, Osmoregulation. Digestion, Biotech, Nervous System and Aging.

For me, Endocrine System, Digestive System and Nervous System are quite annoying. But some topic are nearly all covered in high school which only need to memorize the words. all the PPTs are uploaded to canvas before lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Herrup is really nice, interesting teaching, a lot jokes and always tried his best to explain difficult concepts.  But he is going to leave HKUST in the following spring, and won't teach this course anymore.

Prof. Liang is also good. But the contents he taught turn out to be the most difficult in the exams. Had better spend more time on reviewing his contents. and several his questions (in midterm) aren't included in his PPT.

Dr. Lam just taught 3 lectures but he is very responsible and keep sending us emails to summarize the contents.


All of them are very helpful and willing to answer questions after/before lectures and through email. Prof. Liang also collected the questions he received by email and send them to us.
reviews.comment_grading:
grade is decided by the midterm and final exam evenly. the final isn't cumulative, the contents before midterm aren't included. both exams only have around 50 MC questions and takes 2 hours. I think the midterm is more difficult than final.

in midterm, the mean is 32.7 out of 52(or 51 i'm not sure) and SD is 8.0
in final, the mark is unknown and they reveal the final grade directly.
reviews.comment_workload: no hw, no attendance requirement, but preparing the exams need a lot time.

reviews.author: halo123
reviews.comment_content: More in-depth content of DSE biology. Not too hard to understand. Most challenging topic is probably Development.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Herrup is really good at illustrating complex concepts into simple ideas. He often tells jokes and punchlines in lesson and make the lesson more interesting. I enjoyed his lesson the most.
Lam is from Hong Kong so you can ask him questions in Cantonese after lesson. He often use iprs in lesson and allow us to understand us truly understand some difficult concepts in class (not for attendance purpose so don't worry if you don't want to attend lectures). He speaks softly so you should probably get a seat in the front rows. He explains the content clearly and he is a good teacher too.
You have to use a few lessons to adjust to Liang's accent. His powerpoint includes all the content and you often don't know which part is the most important / will be tested in the exam. However, he is willing to answered your questions and he is passionate in his teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
midterm 50% and final 50% to final grade.
1 sd above in midterm, mark is unknown in the final ( I feel good about the exam), only B+ at last.
reviews.comment_workload: No hw. Attendance is not required.

reviews.author: Dcture
reviews.title: overall introduction of biology
reviews.comment_content: it is like a summary of what I have learnt about Biology in high school. after midterm, the content was more of medical school.
reviews.comment_teaching:
professor HERRUP is really really NICE. he reply my email patiently and never complain about my stupid questions. such a pity that he will be leaving next year.
professor LAM sent us summaries of his lectures every time. this is quite useful for me to comprehend and made it easier to review.
professor LIANG talks fast and I could not understand him every now and then but he did encourage us to ask questions and stimulated me to think critically.
reviews.comment_workload: exams are mostly from PPTs and if you review them well, it won't be a problem. however, the ppts were too much and I can never review them thoroughly.

reviews.author: miketony
reviews.comment_content:
It is the advanced course of Life Science, it is mainly for the student who has studied Biology in the Secondary School and studied LIFS 1901.

Topics are mainly similar to HKDSE Biology, the details can look the other comments. (1/3 basic stuff, 2/3 advanced kinds of stuff)

The Topic " Development" and DNA is the most difficult parts in this course.

You can skip the lectures and just play back the lecture video on the canvas.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Liang: his English is quite good, easy to understand. And his ppt slides are well- organized, you can know what you have learnt in his lectures. But sometimes he will talk about his research on neurobiology.

Lam: he is Hong Kong people and every time he will do the iPRS to help you clarify your knowledge so that you can know what you dun understand. Also, he will email to you to talk about what you have learnt in his lecture and something that you need to focus on. I personally recommend his lecture and try not to skip his lecture.

Herrup: quite a humour, always make the atmosphere well in the lectures. But sometimes cant easily to know what he teaches. He is quite boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
Personally, I think this course is not as bad as other people think. It requires you to remember all the stuff.
However, if you remember all the stuff, you must get at least C+.

I got around 65-70% in midterm
Final exam don't know
Final grade: B-
reviews.comment_workload: Zero Workload, No assignment and essay, just have midterm and final.

reviews.author: paperdoll99^^
reviews.comment_content: The content was based on Inquiry into Life 14th/15th edition. The contents of midterm exam are not included in the Final exam. And because all three professors are making up the exam questions, their question styles are also different. So try to focus during class.
reviews.comment_teaching: There are three professors this semester: Proff.LAM, LIANG, and Herrup. The explanation is explainable, but I personally liked Proff. Herrup's class the most. But personally, ppt is the most important thing.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is just ok. What I mean by this is that if you try your best, you'll be able to get B. I am not sure how to get A, because I haven't got one, though. But I guess PPT was the msot important source of the study.
reviews.comment_workload: There's no workload required during whole semester. So it's A!

reviews.author: cindylsy
reviews.comment_content:
Most of the topics have included in the syllabus of DSE biology, but teaching in a more difficult and detailed way.
Before midterm:
Circulatory System
Lymphatic and Immune System
Digestive System
Respiratory System
Urinary System

After midterm:
Nervous System
Endocrine System
Reproductive System
Development & Aging
Chromosomal Inheritance
Gene Inheritance
Biotechnology
reviews.comment_teaching:
Herrup Karl: He teaches well. He uses simple words to explain difficult concepts and all his lessons I attended, I never slept since he is good at keeping lessons interesting.
Lam Yeung: He teaching is good,  but he often speaks softly that students at the back may not hear what he is saying/talking about.
reviews.comment_grading: absolute wordings are needed, different from the secondary school that knowing the concept and explain with your own wording is OK.
reviews.comment_workload: NO assignment, what affect your gradings is just Midterm and final

reviews.author: eejj
reviews.comment_content: This course will cover basic biological material from central dogma to physiological system.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Overall teaching is really good when it compared to other courses except professor Liang.
Professor Herrup and Lam are the best professors for teaching in ust!!
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is generous.
I got 1SD above for the midterm, and final grade wasn't released.
Then, I finally got A for this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is adequate since there are just 2 exams.
Though this course requires considerable amounts of memorization, you can easily get good grade if you thoroughly review the slides..

reviews.author: Ming_hillman
reviews.title: General ge biology
reviews.comment_content: Mainly human physiology (many of them learned in high schl) and genetics and evolution. Some additional information to the biological knowledge to high schl biology.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Liang teaches things in a very detailed manner, which turn out to have many things to be memorized. 3nd best prof.
Lam speak so softly, better sit in front rows. 2nd best prof.
Herrup has a very clear powerpoint notes. Best prof.
reviews.comment_grading:
No grades yet.
Since the exam grades, hvnt been given, (just finished midterm)
reviews.comment_workload: No homework. Mainly pend most of the time studying

reviews.author: sytsangac
reviews.title: Short Review
reviews.comment_content: There are so many things to memorize. One p p t has at least 1 0 0 pages with so many details and advance knowledge from what u have learnt in secondary school. It takes lot of time to just finish revising one chapter.
reviews.comment_teaching: The p p t is so long that prof would skip a lot and talks fast. It would be a bit difficult to catch up.
reviews.comment_grading: Despite the heavy workload, the grading is fair. I reach the mean and I got C range at last.
reviews.comment_workload: Both Midterm and Exam are in M C Form.

reviews.comment_content: In depth version of DSE bio. Professors might also share some findings from their research(not tested). Lecture videos provided.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite slow paced for all professors(like many other science course), but overall clear and easy to understand. Watching lecture videos at 1.5x speed is way more efficient.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. Mid term above mean by 1 sd. Didn't get to finish revising all content for final. Final grade A. If you want to get a really good grade, 3 days is not enough.
reviews.comment_workload: No hw, only mid term and final.

reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is good. I've got 50/59 in the mid-term exam and I don't know the marks of the final exam. Finally, I've got an A grade.
reviews.comment_workload: All the exams are in MC format and no assignments are given so doing revision is the only thing to do in this course.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Wong's teaching seemed interesting at first.
However, his tune was too low and he spoke too slowly and soon he started repeating his words again and again. What he kept repeating is also somewhat unrelated to the course. But he claimed that he has already retired and was just coming back to help. so I am not sure whether you would meet him again.

Ko's teaching is organized and good but the topic he taught is somewhat easier than others that just looking at the powerpoint is enough.

Tang's teaching is not that boring as some people describe. It is actually quite good.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got 4 in dse biology
I attended lessons only when the topic is new to me but have spent more time (5 days) memorizing the details.
got 47/59 in midterm while the top score was 55, lowest score was 22, mean was 41.7, with SD 7.38.
final marks are unknown.
Got A- at the end.

Midterm (40%)
Final Exam (60%)
both are mc
no short or long question

no assignment or attendance
just final and midterm
lecture videos are provided
I have heard how difficult this course is in fall sem and judging from the quiz provided on canvas which is not counted into the grading. This is true.
The questions were much easier and fewer details were tested in spring sem.
overall it is fair as long as you memorize those things you could get good marks

reviews.author: Magnesium
reviews.comment_content: Very basic biology knowledge for undergraduate learning. What you learn is essential for your further study.
reviews.comment_teaching: Both professors are quite good overall. Prof. Herrup's English is very delightful (it's not fast if you try LIFS 2040). Both professors may talk about their study (cancer for Liang, neurology for Herrup), that part is a little bit difficult and quite interesting but not covered in the exam.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair. Although I'm not a LIFS major student and I had only learned high school biology before. After not very hardworking study I can still get A. I think some basic knowledge in CHEM is helpful.
reviews.comment_workload: No assignment or attendance required.

reviews.author: çŸ³é ­
reviews.title: Looks like it's not about concepts (wrong)
reviews.comment_content:
As for someone who is interested in biology,it's quite fun and need time to digest especially DNA and neuroscience. Others (I think) are not much different from DSE and easy to follow if you read the ppt carefuly.
Need to remember a bunch of Latin in development.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Liang always talks about his research and he became a vegetarian because a bunch of reasons, I nearly fell asleep.

Lam was quite interactive, and uses videos to keep up the mood.But maybe it's the topic I guess (development), the atmosphere was still little awkward.

Herrup was great most of the time, especially then talking about neuroscience. In some other topics sometimes he just reads the ppt and seemed not interested. He uses fun examples but becareful that you need to treat them seriously,because it is either important, or it will show up in the exam
reviews.comment_grading:
The exams are MCs only
The ppts mostly talks about the mechanism of something, and that's why everyone is memorising everything. It's true, but not enough to get a good grade. There are questions (beware of herrup) that are completely untouched by the ppt, that require you to understand the concepts and express it using the mechanism,thus the answer.
Also some questions are quite long and complicated, those are the ones that need concepts
reviews.comment_workload: No homework

Prof. Herrup explains concepts really clearly so relatively easy to understand.

Dr. Lam's ppts are very organized and he explains it quite well.

Prof. Liang's ppt has fewer slides. But a lot of text, diagrams, pictures in each slide, and he talks quite fast.

You might need to find more information from the textbook in addition to lecturer's ppt.

50% Midterm Exam
50% Final Exam (not cumulative)
Only multiple choice questions
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignment required.
Only two examinations but lots of materials to memorize.

reviews.comment_content:

Chromosomal basis of inheritance (24)

As you can see most topic are the ones we learn in Dse . except some like biotech, development, aging.etc However every topic is a bit advanced comparing to dse. but it's not hard to understand in fact it's easy but lots and lots of thing to remember basically everything that appeared in the power points.besides, it's quite interesting (to me ).So if you have a good grade in DSE(5 or above ) this course is just a piece of cake , just may consume some time. but to the others...........it might be a really hard time .
reviews.comment_teaching:
you will be teach by three lecturer- Phillip herrup and liang .I would say phillip> herrup> liang.

Liang: mainlander his English has a bit accent but not hard to hear in fact, satisfactory enough after comparing to other lecturers in ust. will go off topic which is helping you to understand, but you may feel not consistent.most people think it's boring so am I. keep falling asleep

Herrup: the head of the life science department ( Jesus!!) he's an interesting person very good and presented with a good sense of humor. you will really I mean really!! enjoy his lecture. However, at some point, you will feel he is bullshitting because the content is too high-level for most people . and it may not appear in Exam.

Phillip: hong konger  very good at explaining. basically, you won't feel any confuse during the lesson
he also handles rhythm of the class perfectly won't to much or too less. He will also give some examples of the exam (save my life)

All lecture will be record and you can review in canvas

mid-term (50%)
final(50%)
I think the grading is not quite good  
I have 5* in Dse
I also perform above 1SD in midterm
final won't release but still, I perform quite well
But turns out I only have B
probably because there are too many genius in class

reviews.author: bbyun
reviews.title: Don't Procrastinate
reviews.comment_content:
Basically a continuum of your high school courses in life science, except that they go in depth in certain fields of biology.

You learn about many organ systems, such as Circulatory Systsem, Digestive System, Nervous System, Endocrine System, and Lymphatic System.

On top of this, you will learn basic molecular biology as well as some fundamental materials in biotechnology.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Herrup is very good at explaining course materials and information, and makes the overall lecture very interesting.

I sometimes lose my focus in Professor Liang's lecture, due to his pronunciation errors as well as disorganized lecture Powerpoint.

Professor Lam's lecture is also very informative and interesting.

However it depends on you whether you can fully understand the course materials. After you study with their lecture videos and ppt, you still will have to ask to the professor directly if you are curious or struggling in some materials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Just like all life science courses, the grading is quite harsh.

The overall score is divided by two, which are the mid-term exam and the final exam. The score distribution is 50% by 50%. The course does not take attendance and provides lecture videos to students who miss the lecture, which is very helpful.

Both are in the similar level of difficulty, but due to relative scoring you should not expect getting a very high score in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are no assignments in this course, but just the two exams.

However, the exams cover a lot of materials, so I suggest you not to procrastinate over all the two exams. If you do not procrastinate and try to keep your study on track, you will not feel any workload in this course.

reviews.author: hhh
reviews.comment_content: The class contains the basic knowledge of human's system and related common disease. It is really abundant and useful for those who want to major lifs.

Herrup is a foreigner and majors in neural system, his class has more fun since he is a fun guyğŸ˜In fact, I never listen carefully...(I think if you go through the ppt thoroughly that's pretty enough.)

reviews.comment_workload: I have to say the workload is the heaviest among my all courses. Every class we have 60-80 pages of ppt and every page there are so many new words!!!!! I really suggest that you should begin your review for midterm or final as early as possible.

reviews.author: Aug.d
reviews.comment_content: Covers most human physiology topics and genetics. Not much new content if you took IB biology - although there's quite a few of new info in genetics. But in some topics IB explained things in more depth which even things out I guess.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both professors are enthusiastic in their class. Professor Liang sometimes tends to drift while talking, likes to talk about his research a lot. He also reads from the powerpoint but that's good because he puts a lot of information in his ppt which makes it easier to revise. One thing he could fix is talking over the informational videos he makes us watch.

Professor Herrup keeps lectures very interesting, making jokes and explaining things in a way that sticks. He explains more than reading the powerpoint so you should at least go to his classes because there's not a lot of information in his ppts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is average. 50% midterm 50% finals, liked the fact that there weren't any additional homework or group projects. All questions were multiple choice and multiple answers type of questions.

They uploaded all students' results for both exams. I got high above average for both exams and got an A. They didn't give any s.d so I'm not sure what the boundary exactly is.
reviews.comment_workload: The course covers a lot of content so the workload's heavy for students who want a good enough grade but there weren't any homework assigned.

reviews.author: Hooleea
reviews.title: Recommend This Course
reviews.comment_content: First half, you'll learn about development of biology field and detailed mechanisms of cells. Second half, you'll learn systems such as circulatory, digestive, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professors focus in class. They do know what they have to teach, and what info is needed to understand a concept. I could tell how hard they prepared for the class through the powerpoint they use in class. I wish students who are asking in class get to use the microphone that the professor is using. The professor answers a student's questions, but the thing is, other students do not know what he/she asked.
reviews.comment_grading: Multiple answers multiple choice questions are quite tricky. Otherwise, you can get a good grade if you totally understand all the concepts and memorized information on powerpoint.
reviews.comment_workload: High workload if you are a hard-working student since there are many concepts to study.

reviews.author: biochemnerd
reviews.title: Its all good if you have taken bio in high school lol..
reviews.comment_content:
The course is basic intro stuff like DNA/Genetics, Evolution, various organ systems (reproductive, digestive, excretion, respiration, cardiovascular, nervous) and some general stuff like biotech and nutrition.
Textbook not needed, but you can buy it if you want practice and extra reading to well-understand concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Liang is funny and has extensive knowledge on the subjects of DNA/biotech. He often likes to ask students in lecture, and focuses on asking/explaining the experimental ways through which discoveries are made. Although he often reads from the powerpoints, he explains things well.
Prof Herrup is same, funny and likes to keep things interesting during lectures with his funny expression and analogies. The only thing is that you should attend his lec/watch the video as he often talks more than he puts in the slides. Also he has some extra "fun" facts in ppts, so its helpful to go to lecture and figure out what is imp for exam.
Both prof are helpful to answer questions after lectures as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
One midterm (50%) and one final (50%), the percentage can vary based on instructors.
We had both exams as multiple choice, and multiple answer type questions.
The mean grade is around B-, which is pretty good since it doesnt require too much effort.
reviews.comment_workload:
Most of the content is relative to the course and at an appropriate level. If you study well for the exam and go to lecture/watch lecture video it should be fine.
For students with weak english, it might be hard to cope up with the vocab sometimes, but you get used to it eventually and the instructors are understanding of that.

reviews.author: Freda
reviews.comment_content: Quite manageable for students who have studied Biology in DSE. Not much things are new. Some new concept that are a bit difficult but they will not appear in exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Herrup is good at explaining concepts. His powerpoints are with few words so you need to attend his lecture or watch video to understand his points.
Prof. Liang wants to teach us so much difficult things so sometimes he went off topic. And he actually just copy text from the book to the powerpoint and read it out. Still he is quite funny and teach quite clearly.
reviews.comment_grading: If you are at around the mean/median you will get a B.
reviews.comment_workload: Just one midterm and one final exam. Contents are not cumulative.

reviews.author: Wfchu
reviews.comment_content:
There will be a review of DSE syllabus and most of the HKDSE biology topics will be deeply investigated during the class. Mostly are human physiology and some are microbiology.  Much time is needed to revise the physiology vocabs, also the flow charts.
However, the content will be more than what you've encountered during your secondary school and you have to revise the powerpoint and your notes after classes.
reviews.comment_teaching:
IF you are impressed by life science, surely you can manage all the stuff during classes. Apart from the powerpoint slides, you should always stay awake for the extra information added by instructor.
Good command of English is an advantage for students who take this course as you will encounter some sophisticated words that are needed to remember.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair.
Just need to revise notes before mid-term and final exams. Most would get B range from this course.
reviews.comment_workload: As long as you compile your notes regularly (supposed you've jotted notes), you can manage to revise and recall the inter-connected topics taught in the sem. and the quantity of content is frankly afordable

reviews.comment_content:
The content is a continuation of LIFS 1901 (General Biology I) and is almost completely focused on human biology. Topics include:
Wong:

Immune System
Digestive System
Respiratory System
Excretory System

reviews.comment_teaching: Both professors are quite clear and explain the concepts well. They are also helpful and willing to answer any questions. But the lectures for both can get very boring and as they only read from the lecture slides it's not necessary to attend.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm and Final only (distribution not specified, probably 50-50 or 40-60). The exams are mostly MCQs and not very hard.

reviews.title: Difficult, testing the limit of memory but give you a solid foundation
reviews.comment_content:
I would say it is too much but it's the fact that you cannot avoid.  Every lecture is averaging 100 slides. Therefore, get prepared.

Also, i would say that the lectures taught by Karl are quite a lot more difficult than Jessica's. They require much much more understanding than the topics Jessica teaches. Especially the development part. Therefore, again, get prepared.

Although there is too much content, you'll need that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both professors are really really good. Both will listen to us carefully and patiently answer our questions after class.

Also, they both are caring professors. For example, Karl intentionally said he will allow Christian students to not attend lectures about evolution if they fell uncomfortable about what he said and he will provide help to them and try to adjust the marks.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think it is quite good. I was 0.5 SD above mean in mid-term. They did not release the score in final and i got A finally.

Therefore....I don't know! ^^''
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework. Just testing your limit of memory even if you study the notes regularly. (You still need short memory)

So, good luck!

reviews.author: diudiu
reviews.title: è³‡è¨Šé‡å¤§ä½†ä¿‚å””é›£
reviews.comment_content:
Two halves, first half (Herrup) centers around DNA, evolution, reproduction, and genetics, topics which are examined in midterm. The second half (Tang) is mostly about human physiology, with two lectures of biotechnology and application closing the course.

Herrup loves to add a lot of extra details in his half, and some might find themselves in severe information overload, if you
(a) are not very good at language esp. listening
(b) do not possess a good foundation of biology
(c) are too lazy to look up his bonus materials
Herrup's part, however, is easily, hands down, the funnest section in the course.

Tang's half is about the different systems in humans. Not much to learn here, and the lectures are perfectly skippable. Not that you could åƒä¸­å­¸è€æœ¬, but the workload here is near zero compared to Herrup's part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I intended to give an A here because of Prof Herrup but a C for Dr Tang, so here it is, a B.
Many would say Professor Herrup speaks way too fast and covers too many complex course contents, but seriously I think this is just the way native speakers teach. It is simply natural for the professor to try and share as much as his knowledge to students.
Dr. Tang, meanwhile, is a typical Hong Kong lecturer. She speaks with a pretty Hongkong-ish accent you might find......rather.......hypnotizzzing. Well in her defense she got the way less interesting part, i.e. human physiology, a topic largely overlapping with DSE biology.
reviews.comment_grading:
A very intriguing system was used in the examinations. Along with the multiple choice questions (60 for midterm, 100 for final), there were "multiple answer multiple choice" questions with some 7 to 10 choices from which you have to choose up to 5 correct options. These questions make up 20 marks in each exam.

Not sure about the grading since it was kind of irrelevant to me, but here are some stats.
76.4% midterm, >2.4 SD, mean 49.6%, max 84%
87.2% final, mean 54.8% iirc
--> A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Huh what can I say here? No assignments, no readings, non-cumulative exams, the workload here was very low.
To be honest I only revised for
3 days for midterm
23 hours for final
from scratch and still turned out fine

Well unless you intend on self-churring by actually reading the papers included in Herrup's powerpoints I suppose. lel

reviews.author: iamthrookeed
reviews.comment_content:
In-depth teaching for materials that mostly have been covered in high school (genetics, DNA, evolution, development and ageing, biotechnology, and organ systems: reproduction, nervous system, lymphatic & immune system, circulatory system, respiratory system, digestive system, excretory system)
The content is from Inquiry into Life textbook by Sylvia S. Mader, 14th ed. You might consider buying it if you want to read the additional material from the book, but it's not really important. The questions for self-practice is quite helpful in familiarising you with the questions in the midterm and final, although I'd say it was not really similar and sufficient.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Herrup is good but Dr. Tang is not. The lecture videos are available so you don't need to attend the lectures. Dr. Tang only reads from her slides anyway.
reviews.comment_grading: I think you need to get at least 0.5SD (or 0.6SD/0.7SD) above mean for the midterm and cram for the final for 1 week (it's relative, depends on how efficient you are) to get A range, but you should really put a big effort on your final.
reviews.comment_workload: No reading is required, just need to memorise a lot of things. No assignment. No attendance for lectures.

reviews.author: USTian
reviews.comment_content:
The course covered topics mainly on DNA, genetics and human biology. If you are interested in human biology and disease, this course will be quite enjoyable.

1. DNA Structure (Ch. 25), Control of Gene Expression
2. Human Genetics - Genes & Chromosomes (Ch. 23~24)
3. Reproduction (Ch. 21)
4. Evolution (Ch. 27)
5. Endocrine System (Ch. 20)
6. Development & Aging (Ch. 22)
7. Nervous System (Ch. 17)
8. Lymphatic & Immune Systems (Ch. 13), Infectious Diseases
9. Circulatory System (Ch. 12)
10. Respiratory System (Ch. 15)
11. Processing & Nutrition - Digestive System (Ch. 14)
12. Osmoregulation & Excretion - Excretory system (Ch. 16)
12. Biotechnology (Ch. 26)

* Chapter numbers based on textbook chapters of <Inquiry into Life> by Sylvia S. Mader, 14th ed..
reviews.comment_teaching: I went to Prof. Herrup's lectures, but barely went to Prof. Tang's. Both professors did post videos of the lectures, so you could watch them, or just read the PPTs and the suggested textbook.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm Exam - 40%
Final Exam - 60%

The exams are noncumulative, fortunately.
I got 1.2 SD above mean (mean = 49.6%) for the midterm, and didn't have time to go over 2 chapters for the final, but still received an A.
reviews.comment_workload: There are no assignments or compulsory readings since only the exams count for marks. I did read the suggested textbook <Inquiry into Life> by Sylvia S. Mader, and found it quite helpful. But if you don't seem to have enough time to go through the textbook, don't, because it does have a lot of unimportant information too. Try out the textbook questions though, because one of them that I just skimmed through actually appeared on the final exam.

reviews.comment_content: Everything is about basic biology, which most people already get from highschool. Not demanding at all.

reviews.author: Asflsy
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly focused on systems in human body, respiratory system, nervous system,  digestive system, etc,etc. Some other parts (like DNA, evolution) are also talked about in several chapters.
Totally 24 chapters. Knowledge taught is very rich and detailed.
The most difficult part is the vocabulary for many nonnative English speakers like me.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Karl is humorous and responsible. He can somehow explain those complicated concepts very clear.
Jessica is not so organized as Karl but still good and clear.
reviews.comment_grading: To be fair, the grading is okay. I got both my exams below mean and a B-. It should be easy for many.

10 hours a week might not be enough.

Fair grade

Biology lovers may get better grade.

50% mid-term
50% final
No hw, prs is not for grading
but there are quite a lot of content that you need to study
